title.value: Integer Programming Games: A Gentle Computational Overview
title.justification: This is the title provided in the paper.
title.quote: Integer Programming Games: A Gentle Computational Overview

extractions.description: This tutorial presents a computational overview on computing Nash equilibria in Integer Programming Games (IPGs). It provides background, classifies state-of-the-art algorithms for these games, proposes a taxonomy of algorithmic ingredients needed for equilibrium computation, and compares different types of IPGs to highlight their properties.

type.justification: The paper systematically reviews, classifies, and compares algorithms while also presenting quantitative and qualitative comparisons of game models.
type.quote: ...we systematically review and classify the state-of-the-art algorithms to compute Nash equilibria. We propose an essential taxonomy of the algorithmic ingredients needed to compute equilibria, and we describe the theoretical and practical challenges associated with equilibria computation. Finally, we quantitatively and qualitatively compare a sequential Stackelberg game with a simultaneous IPG to highlight the different properties of their solutions.

name.justification: The paper focuses on computational aspects and algorithmic efficiency, which are key concerns in Operations Research.
name.quote: Compared to the solution of a single optimization problem, the solutions of IPGs should account for the added complexity resulting from the strategic interaction.

name.justification: The paper addresses Nash equilibria and computational methods in the context of game theory.
name.quote: In this tutorial, we provide an overview of the motivations, the computational aspects, and the challenges associated with IPGs. Specifically, we primarily focus on the algorithmic aspect connected to the computation of the Nash equilibria of IPGs.

name.justification: The paper involves solving optimization problems within the framework of game theory.
name.quote: In a Nash equilibrium, all the decision-makers make mutually-optimal (i.e., rational) decisions, and no single decision-maker is incentivized to deviate to a different set of decisions.

name.justification: This model is explicitly discussed as an algorithm to compute mixed Nash equilibria in IPGs.
name.quote: First, we consider the Sample Generation Method (SGM) from Carvalho et al. [8], an algorithm to compute a mixed Nash (and correlated) equilibrium in IPGs with separable and Lipschitz continuous payoff functions.

is_contributed.justification: The Sample Generation Method (SGM) is referenced as an existing method, not introduced by the authors of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: First, we consider the Sample Generation Method (SGM) from Carvalho et al. [8]

is_executed.justification: The focus of the paper is on theoretical and computational aspects rather than the specific execution environment of the algorithms.
is_executed.quote: ...an algorithm to compute a mixed Nash (and correlated) equilibrium in IPGs with separable and Lipschitz continuous payoff functions.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared with other algorithms in the tutorial for computing mixed Nash equilibria.
is_compared.quote: ...we will focus on three algorithms to compute pure Nash equilibria and omit the generalized equilibria...

referenced_paper_title.value: Computing equilibria for integer programming games
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper focuses on the Sample Generation Method (SGM).
referenced_paper_title.quote: First, we consider the Sample Generation Method (SGM) from Carvalho et al. [8]

name.justification: This model extends SGM and is used to enumerate mixed Nash equilibria when players control only integer variables.
name.quote: Second, we analyze the Exhaustive Sample Generation Method (eSGM) from Crönert and Minner [13], an algorithm extending SGM that can enumerate all the mixed Nash equilibria when players only control integer variables (i.e., ki = 0).

is_contributed.justification: The Exhaustive Sample Generation Method (eSGM) is referenced as an existing method, not introduced by the authors of this paper.

is_compared.quote: Finally, we analyze Cut-and-Play (CnP) from Carvalho et al. [7], an algorithm to compute an equilibrium for nonconvex games with separable payoffs, including IPGs, by outer approximation of the set of strategies for each player...
